Blane, you join me in pointing out (as I did in my blog) that more banks should have been allowed to fail, as "Failure is and should always be a possible outcome of any enterprise in a free market. By protecting disreputable banks from failure, the government simply robbed prudent banks of an opportunity to buy the failed bank assets for pennies on the dollar. Scooping up failed assets is the reward prudent firms reap for being responsible."

But your idea "The "housing bubble" was at least partially created by a cheap money policy financed by deficit spending...." doesn't hold together logically. Deficit spending requires borrowing on the open market, and so soaks up money as various investors purchase the increase in treasury bills. The normal effect (without Fed intervention, quantitative easing) is that as more money is taken up by government, interest rates will then *rise* relative to what they would have been. Of course, as you should know, Fed quantitafive easing did not happen before or during the housing bubble of 2000-2007. So if federal deficit spending in 2002-2005, during the heart of the bubble inflation tended to naturally raise interest rates, then why did rates in fact generally trend *down* during the federal deficit spending of 2002-2005?

Simple. For exactly the reason you could read during those years, and over and over: the "worldwide savings glut."

That's a barrage of cheap money from *overseas*, especially from China.
